channel.title: Links on Nathan Lane
channel.description: Recent content in Links on Nathan Lane

item.title: On developmentalism, planning, & early big data in Allende's Chile.
item.description: "In Allende’s Chile, a futuristic op room was to bring socialism into the computer age." Link: From the New Yorker - `The Planning Machine' By Evgeny Morozov ``The consultant, Stafford Beer, had been brought in by Chile’s top planners to help guide the country down what Salvador Allende, its democratically elected Marxist leader, was calling `the Chilean road to socialism.' Beer was a leading theorist of cybernetics—a discipline born of midcentury efforts to understand the role of communication in controlling social, biological, and technical systems.

item.title: A great primer on cleaning OCRd data with Python & Regular Expressions.
item.description: Link: Cleaning OCR’d text with Regular Expressions Often the pain of optical character recognition isn't the OCRing procedure itself, it is cleaning the tiny, little inconsistencies that plague OCRd content. This is especially true when we OCR historical material: even high quality scans can have a speckle or two that get recognized as gibberish. Adept use of Regular Expressions (regex) coupled with simple Python (or Ruby scripts--or heck, even Notepad++) can be a powerful means of removing nasty errors from OCRd text/CSV files.

item.title: The data on white anxiety over Hispanic immigration
item.description: The data on white anxiety over Hispanic immigration (Via my pal, UMass Prof. Arin Dube) A fantastic piece on racial anxiety and views on race. A nice little combination of academic research and polling insights.

item.title: Historic Aggregate Data for Korea, 1910-1945 -- and beyond.
item.description: Historic Aggregate Data for Korea, 1910-1945 -- and beyond. Here is a cool batch of datasets (mainly aggregates!) from Korea’s Nakseongdae Institute of Economic Research, one of which is a nice collection of material covering the colonial Japanese period of Korea (1910-1945). [Just run that sucker through Google translate.] If you’re doing data work in economic history, your life is messy. Even more, if you’re doing historical work for a developing country, finding the data is often a massive part of the job.
